results.title: Ecology of a hot spring: life at high temperatures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Uses the hot springs of Yellowstone National Park as a laboratory for the study of organisms that can survive the effects of high temperatures. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.creator_credit: Barry Stoner and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)

results.title: Plankton and the open sea
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Pictures typical forms of plankton and demonstrates the importance of minute plankton organisms to marine food chains. Also shows how plankton is studied. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The High arctic biome
results.creator_credit: Hugh O'Connor, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Describes the constant struggle of plants and animals for survival in the harsh environment of the high arctic biome. Photographed on the arctic coastal lands of Canada. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hugh O’Connor, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Riddles of Sand and Ice
results.creator_credit: Barry Stoner and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Miracle Planet”.
Volume 5 examines glacial ice, its movement over thousands of years and what we can learn from it. The massive changes that the planet has endured are now being compounded by the effects of humans on the Earth’s surface. The natural cycle of the Earth’s orbit suggests that long-term, the planet is getting colder, yet it is showing signs of warming due to the increased levels of man-made gases in the atmosphere.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Stoner and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)

results.title: Home in the high country
results.creator_credit: Trevor Larner and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Trevor Larner first discovered the Victorian high country as a teenager. He initially wanted to get to the highest point, but then fell in love with the vegetation and beauty of the Alpine region. Eventually he started working there maintaining infrastructure, building ski lodges and repairing the huts of the early pioneers. When Trevor went back to visit in 2008, it felt like he was coming home.

results.title: Community
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Defines the ecological community as a complex network of interrelationships among a group of plants and animals adapted to the same general physical conditions, food chains and food webs.

results.title: The Grasslands
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Illustrates the ecological interrelationships of the grasslands biome, giving examples of typical food chains. Shows the location of the world’s grasslands, expains how they may have originated an describes their importance as food producing areas.

results.title: Succession on lava
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”
Illustrates the destruction caused by a volcanic eruption in Hawaii, and examines the difficulties encountered by the first forms of life that re-appear. Traces the stages of ecological succession, from the blue-green algae to the re-establishment of a mature biotic community.
